sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a circular loop
message_1: A circular loop of radius 0.2 meters carries a current of 5 amperes. What is the magnetic field at a point located 0.1 meters from the center of the loop?
message_2:
To find the magnetic field at a point located 0.1 meters from the center of the loop, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a circular loop:

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, R is the radius of the loop, and x is the distance from the center of the loop.

Given values:
I = 5 A
R = 0.2 m
x = 0.1 m
μ₀ = 4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A

Plugging in the values:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 5 A * (0.2 m)²) / (2 * ((0.2 m)² + (0.1 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 5 A * 0.04 m²) / (2 * (0.05 m²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) T * 0.04 m²) / (2 * 0.125 m³)

B = (3.2π × 10^(-7) T) / 0.125 m³

B ≈ 8.03 × 10^(-6) T

The magnetic field at a point located 0.1 meters from the center of the loop is approximately 8.03 × 10^(-6) T (Tesla).
